But research shows that focusing on how we do things - praising effort, trying new approaches, and solving problems - helps us develop new skills and improve our talents.

The rover on Mars takes samples of the air around it every now and then. In 2014, it discovered something interesting - methane was present in the air. Methane is a simple molecule that is also found in natural gas. One important thing about methane is that it doesn't last very long, only a few hundred years. This means that there must be something on Mars that's producing more of it. NASA says that Mars releases thousands of tons of methane at one time. The amount of methane changes throughout the year, kind of like how we breathe in and out.

When Carol Dweck, a psychologist from Stanford University, was just starting her career, she gave a group of 10-year-olds some math problems that were slightly too difficult for them. Some kids really enjoyed the challenge and thought it was cool that they could learn new things. They believed that their abilities could grow stronger over time. This mindset is called a 'growth mindset' because it focuses on what you can achieve in the future. On the other hand, some children felt like their intelligence was being tested and they had failed. They thought that their abilities were fixed and couldn't be changed. Some of these kids even said they might cheat in the future to get ahead. Others looked for someone who did worse than them so they could feel better about themselves.

Horror movies often take place in deserted areas. This could be an old hospital with no one around, a spooky empty house, or even a town where everyone has left. There's something unsettling about these lonely places. You can't help but wonder what it was like when people lived there and why they moved away. Maybe the silence is also part of the fear - it's very quiet in these places, which can be really scary too. Plus, abandoned areas are perfect for horror movie directors because it's believable that you wouldn't have phone signal there either.

In horror movies, the basement is always a frightening place, no matter what kind of house it is. This is often where something sinister is lurking or where the bad guy has hidden their tools. Basements are usually dark and damp, which makes them even more unsettling. You can only get to the basement by climbing down a narrow staircase. And even when there's nothing unusual happening down there, basements still have an eerie atmosphere.

Gary Collins, an off-duty police officer, was watching the news about the riots in London on TV. He noticed some familiar faces and decided to cut his holiday short to help with identifying them. For six months, he went through hours of CCTV footage, looking closely at people's eyes and other features. In the end, he managed to identify 190 individuals. His help was very important for the police investigation. Even with so much footage - over 200,000 hours! - special computer software could only recognize one person.

I find it really interesting to think about how we can improve ourselves as humans by using technology. Just imagine if you could put a computer chip in your brain! In the future, we'll be able to do just that and make our brains work better. We'll be able to solve math problems faster, hear sounds more clearly, and remember things more easily. This idea is going to become more normal over time.

The speaker gave a really interesting talk, and some of what they said was very true. For example, think about how parents influence their kids. If we expect teenagers not to be on their phones while doing homework, it's hard when they see their own parents using social media during everyday activities like cooking or waiting at a red light. The speaker also made a good point about people wanting to be in two places at once. So, they switch between talking online and talking in real life. I've seen this happen with my teenage daughter and her friends. They plan to meet up, but then each one is busy chatting online while the others just sit together quietly.

When we hear news stories that make us think the world is getting more violent, it's also good to remember some positive things. Between World War II and 1990, there were many wars that killed over 100,000 people. Today, there are still some civil wars going on, but countries are generally getting along better than they used to. However, terrorism has become a bigger problem in recent years. Since World War II, wars have actually killed more civilians than soldiers. On the other hand, even though civilian deaths are a concern, there is some good news too. While violent crime is still nine times more likely to cause death than political conflict, the number of murders per 100,000 people has actually gone down slightly - from 8 in 2000 to around 5.3 in 2015.

Wasfia has spent her life helping people have their basic rights respected. She's seen many projects in Bangladesh that aimed to educate and train women, but sadly, these efforts often stopped and left nothing behind. Wasfia realized that Bangladesh needed to take a stand for itself, so she combined two things she loves - climbing mountains and fighting for human rights - to try to change people's attitudes towards women in her country. She started climbing while working on humanitarian projects in Tibet and Nepal because most people in Bangladesh have never seen a mountain before. Her campaign seems to be making progress as more and more people from Bangladesh are starting to take notice, not just in Bangladesh but also around the world.

Most people think that countries with few resources are in a very bad situation. They believe these countries are extremely poor, ruled by dictators, and have no chance for real change. However, this is not true. In fact, something amazing is happening. Over the past 20 years, more than 700 million people have become richer and left poverty behind. This means that many fewer children die each year from illnesses, more girls are going to school, and millions of people now have access to clean water.

Many managers try to make their feedback more helpful by saying something nice before criticizing. But when they do this all the time, employees start to think that the nice comments are just a way to make the criticism less harsh. This means the good comments don't mean as much anymore. Instead, positive feedback should be used to praise and motivate people for doing well, not just to soften the blow of something negative.

I'm part of a group called the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Let's forget the scary movie image of a robot like Terminator destroying everything, and think about what's happening now. Military machines like drones, gun turrets, and robots are already being used to kill people with very little human control. The next step could be 'murderbots' that can decide who to kill on their own without being told. To me, this would be very wrong and dangerous for humanity. We need to think carefully about what we ask machines to do.

English is the most popular language for people to learn, with more people studying it than any other language. It's also spoken in the most countries around the world. Although Chinese has the largest number of native speakers, English is widely used globally. Interestingly, there doesn't seem to be a clear connection between how many people speak a language as their first language and how many people learn it as a second language. However, we do see a stronger link between the number of people learning a language and how many countries have people who speak that language.

Your manager pulls you aside and wants to talk about your work on the recent project. You spend all weekend thinking about it, wondering if you did something wrong. On Monday morning, you go to her office and she starts by saying nice things about how well you worked on the project. You're surprised because you think this might be just a way to start giving feedback, like when people say something good, then what they really want to say, and finally something else good again.

The rock album 'Born in the USA' is full of energy and catchy melodies, but its lyrics also have a deep emotional impact. Behind the upbeat songs are stories about the darker side of the American dream. Many of these tracks talk about everyday people who work hard but don't get rich or famous. They express their frustration and anger when life doesn't turn out as they hoped. For example, the song 'Glory Days' is about people in a small town looking back at when they were young and had everything going for them. The song 'Downbound Train' tells the story of a young man whose life falls apart after he loses his job. It's easy to imagine that the artist is drawing from real-life experiences or what could have been if he hadn't become famous. This album shows off the incredible talent of Bruce Springsteen, also known as the Boss.

Lewis wants to see more marine protected areas in the world. He thinks this would help fix the harm that humans are causing by overfishing, polluting, and littering. Lewis has seen the damage himself on his adventures. He's swum over coral reefs that have turned white because of rising water temperatures. He's also seen underwater deserts in the Red Sea with no life and lots of plastic waste. Pugh thinks nature can recover if we give it a chance, but time is running out. If we don't take care of our oceans, we might soon face a big problem that's hard to solve.

Terrie Sharp is a well-known author who has written many successful books. She has even won an award for her crime stories twice! Growing up in Glasgow, she had to be careful and keep out of trouble because where she lived was known for having high levels of crime. As a result, she learned some important skills, like how to open car doors safely. But she never used these skills for bad things - instead, she used them as inspiration for her novels. Now, Terrie is not so shy and enjoys sharing her stories with others by appearing on TV shows and speaking at writing events all over the UK.

Is life getting better or worse? Can we really make progress? Steven Pinker thinks about this big question in his book 'Enlightenment Now'. He says that, overall, things are going well. We're living longer, healthier lives, and we have more freedom and happiness. But the real problem is that some people are attacking important values like using our brains to think critically and relying on science. When leaders and politicians try to get us to be loyal only to our own group, or make us feel hopeless about the future, it's a big danger. If we're not careful, this could cause serious harm to things like democracy and working together as a global community.

In old horror movies, characters were often in trouble and couldn't get help or call the police because they didn't have phones. This made the situation seem more realistic. Now that we all have mobile phones, it's harder to make a scary movie believable. So, filmmakers use a trick: no phone signal! If you're the hero of a horror film, you can be sure that when you really need help, your phone won't work or will run out of battery just as you're trying to call for assistance.

In the 1950s, banana farmers in Central America were facing a big problem. Their most profitable type of banana, called Gros Michel or Big Mike, was dying out. Now, the same thing is happening to its replacement, the Cavendish banana. The Gros Michel banana plant used to be very successful because it had fruit that was easy to transport and tasted sweet. Its thick skin made it less likely to get damaged during transportation. United Fruit, a big company that grew and exported bananas in South America at the time, found ways to grow more bananas quickly and efficiently. They did this by taking cuttings from banana plants instead of growing them from seeds, and planting them close together in fields.

Most spiders have venom that helps them catch their food or kill it. It's not meant to hurt humans. In fact, only 25 out of all known spider species can actually harm us. Even then, most spider bites are just painful and rarely serious. Australia has a famous spider called the Sydney funnel-web spider. Since they developed an antidote in 1981, there have been no deaths from this spider's bite. However, it's still important to be careful around hairy spiders like tarantulas. If you disturb them or make them feel threatened, they can release tiny hairs that get stuck in your skin or eyes. These hairs are very irritating and can cause discomfort.

This type of horror movie is very common. It starts with a group of teenagers having fun, but ends with everyone dying except one girl. At first, this girl is usually shy and not strong. But by the end, she becomes super brave and clever. In most cases, this last girl survives and wins in the end.

To understand where our ability to speak complex sentences comes from, we need to look at how our brains differ from those of other animals. It's not just about brain size; it's also important what else our brains can do and when these abilities evolved. Unfortunately, there aren't many physical clues left by our ancestors that would tell us what language they were capable of speaking. However, we can learn something from the remains of early humans. For example, we can see how their mouths, throats, and tongues developed over time. By around 100,000 years ago, humans had evolved the ability to create complex sounds. Before then, scientists can only make educated guesses about whether early humans communicated using simpler sounds or not.

Society tells us that girls should focus on arts and humanities, while boys are better suited for maths and physics. This is because there aren't many inspiring female role models who work in science-related fields. In cartoons and stories, we often see male characters as scientists, inventors, or astronauts. Unfortunately, the media also portrays scientists as awkward, socially awkward, or isolated from the rest of the world. These stereotypes are not true, but they might discourage girls from pursuing a career in science. If there were more positive female role models in science, it would give girls more confidence and make them feel like they belong in those subjects.

The Scallion newspaper comes out every week and is given away for free in university buildings. It's read by around 10,000 students. The good thing about this paper is that it's written and made entirely by students themselves. A survey shows that most students and staff really like the newspaper because it provides entertainment, helps them learn more about different cultures, and gives them work experience. However, printing all these newspapers costs a lot of money. Another problem is that some students can't easily get their hands on a copy because they have to physically go to the university to pick one up. To make things worse, many copies end up littering the campus.

At Girox Foods, we're seeing a significant number of our staff leave each year - around 12% of our total workforce. While this might not seem like a lot at first, it's actually higher than what's normal in our industry, where the average is about 7%. The main goal of this report is to figure out why some employees aren't fully engaged with their work and what we can do to make the workplace more enjoyable for them. By understanding these reasons, we hope to come up with suggestions that will help us keep our staff happy and reduce the number of people who leave each year.

A lot of what the speaker said makes sense to me. I think it's true that being more connected can make us feel more alone. This isn't a big problem for my age group, who grew up without technology and know how to be by ourselves. We're comfortable with silence and understand that it's okay to have some time to yourself. However, younger people under 20 are different. They're so busy texting and messaging that they never get used to being alone and might miss out on learning to enjoy their own company. Additionally, they learn how to communicate through messages that can be changed, which means they don't develop the skill of having real conversations with someone in front of them.

When you give someone praise, it's better not to follow it with criticism. If you always mix good and bad comments together, people might start ignoring the positive ones. Make sure there are times when you just say something nice without trying to improve anything. Don't feel like you need to find something wrong to say.
